Description: Fragment of lid of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; interior reserved; exterior: tongues between bands at centre; black-figure decoration consisting of confronted bull and lion (of bull, only horn with added red, ear and part of eye remaining; of lion, head, mane with red and shoulder with red remain); pendant rosette with red centre as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Stage 2 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless. The vases in Stage 2 have even more basic rosettes than the vases from Stage 1. Furthermore, the deterioration of the Sphinx and Lion Style appears quite clearly in the execution of the face of the different figures. Boardman suggests that the sherd might belong to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.97a.1894.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 314, no. 1344, pl. 174)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 32, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2132) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
